text: When David had grown very old, they covered him with blankets, but he could not keep warm,
speaker: Narrator

text: so his servants suggested to him, “Let’s look for a young virgin woman to take care of you, your majesty. She will be of use to you if you have her lie down near you so that your majesty may keep warm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they conducted a search throughout the territory of Israel for a beautiful young woman, and Abishag the Shunammite was located and brought to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young woman was absolutely beautiful. She served the king and was very useful to him. The king was not sexually involved with her.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, about this time Haggith’s son Adonijah began to seek a reputation for himself and decided, “I’m going to be king!” So he prepared chariots, cavalry, and 50 soldiers to serve as a security detail to guard him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His father had never challenged him at any time during his life by asking him, “Why are you acting like this?” Adonijah was very handsome and had been born after Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had the support of Zeruiah’s son Joab and of Abiathar the priest, who followed Adonijah and assisted him,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Zadok the priest, Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, Nathan the prophet, Shimei, Rei, and David’s personal elite forces would have nothing to do with Adonijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah sacrificed sheep, oxen, and fatted cattle by the Serpent Stone near En-rogel, inviting all of his relatives, the king’s sons, and all of the men of Judah who worked for the king,
speaker: Narrator

text: but he did not invite Nathan the prophet, Benaiah, David’s personal elite forces, or his brother Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Haven’t you heard?” Nathan asked Solomon’s mother Bathsheba. “Haggith’s son Adonijah has become king and David, our true king, isn’t aware of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you listen to me, you’ll save your life and the life of your son Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Go right now to King David and ask him, ‘Your majesty, you promised your servant that “Your son Solomon will certainly become king after me and will sit on my throne,” didn’t you? So why has Adonijah become king?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Then, while you are still talking to the king, I’ll come in after you and verify your statement.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Bathsheba went to the king in his private room. Now the king was very old, and Abishag the Shunammite was attending to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bathsheba knelt and bowed down to the king, and the king asked her, “What do you wish?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Your majesty,” she replied, “you promised your servant in the name of the Lord your God, ‘Your son Solomon will certainly become king after me and will sit on my throne.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now look, Adonijah has become king, and your majesty is not aware of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah has sacrificed myriads of oxen, fattened cattle, and sheep, and he has invited all of the king’s sons, Abiathar the priest, and Joab the commander of the army, but he has not invited your servant Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as for you, your majesty, everyone in Israel is looking to you to tell them who will sit on your majesty’s throne after you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Otherwise, as soon as your majesty is laid to rest with his ancestors, my son Solomon and I will be branded as traitors.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was still talking to the king, Nathan the prophet arrived.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They informed the king, “Nathan the prophet is here.”
When he had been ushered into the presence of the king, Nathan bowed low in front of the king with his face to the ground
speaker: Narrator

text: and asked, “Your majesty, did you say ‘Adonijah will be king after me and will sit on my throne’?
speaker: Narrator

text: Well now, he went down today and sacrificed lots of oxen, fattened cattle, and sheep, and has invited all the king’s sons, the army commanders, and Abiathar the priest. They’re having a party together and saying, ‘Long live King Adonijah!’
speaker: Narrator

text: Of course, he never invited me, Zadok the priest, Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, nor your servant Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Were you behind this, your majesty, without letting your servants know who would sit on your majesty’s throne after him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Call Bathsheba for me,” King David replied. So she came in and stood in front of the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: “As the Lord lives,” the king said with an oath, “who has redeemed me from all sorts of troubles,
speaker: Narrator

text: I certainly did tell you in the name of the Lord God of Israel, ‘Your son Solomon will be king after me and will sit on my throne in my place.’ I’m certainly going to make this happen today!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “King David,” Bathsheba said as she bowed low in front of the king with her face to the ground, “your majesty, may you live forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get me Zadok the priest,” King David said, “along with Nathan the prophet, and Jehoiada’s son Benaiah.” So they were ushered into the king’s presence
speaker: Narrator

text: and David addressed them. “Take your lord’s servants, have my son Solomon ride on my own mule, and take him down to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Have Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there as king over Israel. Then sound a trumpet and declare ‘Long live King Solomon!’
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, you are to follow him back here, and he is to come and sit on my throne and take my place as king, because I’ve appointed him to be Commander-in-Chief over Israel and Judah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Amen!” replied Jehoiada’s son Benaiah to the king. “May the Lord God of your majesty make this happen!
speaker: Narrator

text: As the Lord has been with your majesty the king, so may he be with Solomon. May he make his throne greater than the throne of your majesty, King David.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, and the special forces and mercenaries went out and had Solomon ride the king’s mule all the way to Gihon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok the priest brought from his tent a horn filled with oil and anointed Solomon, a trumpet was sounded, and everybody yelled out, “Long live King Solomon!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the people followed after him, playing on wind pipes and so full of joy that the earth shook because of all the noise!
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, Adonijah and all of his guests were just finishing their meal when they heard all the noise. “Why is the city in such an uproar?” Joab asked as he heard the trumpet sounds.
speaker: Narrator

text: While he was still asking that question, Jonathan, the son of Abiathar the priest arrived, so Adonijah told him, “Come on in, since you’re a worthy man and are bringing us good news!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “No,” Jonathan answered. “Our lord King David has installed Solomon as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king has sent Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, and the special forces and mercenaries, along with Solomon, who is riding the king’s personal mule.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him in Gihon, and they just left from there rejoicing, and that’s why the city is all in an uproar. That’s the noise that you’ve been hearing!
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon now sits on the royal throne.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition to all of this, the king’s servants have come along to congratulate our lord King David. They’ve been telling David ‘May your God make Solomon’s reputation even more famous than yours, and may he make his throne greater than yours!’ The king has himself bowed in worship on his own bed
speaker: Narrator

text: and said ‘Blessed be the Lord God of Israel, who has provided someone to sit on my throne today. I’ve seen it with my own eyes!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Terrified, all of Adonijah’s guests jumped up and ran away.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afraid of Solomon, Adonijah also jumped up and headed straight for the horns of the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Hey look!” somebody informed Solomon. “Adonijah is terrified of King Solomon! He’s gone out, grabbed hold of the horns of the altar, and now he’s begging King Solomon, ‘Swear to me that you won’t put your servant to death with a sword!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If he’s done nothing wrong, not a hair of his head will be harmed,” Solomon replied. “But if we find evil in him, he’s a dead man.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon sent for him, and he was brought down from the altar. When he had arrived, he fell on his face in front of King Solomon, so Solomon told him, “Go home!”
speaker: Narrator

text: As David’s time to die approached, he addressed his son Solomon with these words:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m headed down the road that everyone who lives on earth travels, so be strong and demonstrate that you’re a grown man
speaker: Narrator

text: by keeping the charge that the Lord your God entrusted to you. Live life his way, keep his statutes, his commands, his ordinances, and his testimonies, just as they’re written down in the Law of Moses, so that you may succeed in everything you do and wherever you go,
speaker: Narrator

text: and so that the Lord may fulfill his promise that he spoke about me when he said, ‘If your sons pay attention to how they live by walking truthfully in my presence with all their heart and with all their soul, you will never lack a man on the throne of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Furthermore, you’re aware of what Zeruiah’s son Joab did to me and to those two commanders of the armies of Israel, Ner’s son Abner and Jether’s son Amasa, whom he killed, and how he shed the blood of wartime during times of peace, staining the very belt he wears around his waist and the sandals he wears on his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: So act consistently with your wisdom, and don’t let him die as a peaceful old man.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be gracious to the descendants of Barzillai the Gileadite, and provide for them in your household, because they helped me when I had to run from your brother Absalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Pay attention now! You have with you Gera’s son Shimei the descendant of Benjamin from Bahurim. He cursed me violently that day when I had to leave for Mahanaim. When he visited me at the Jordan River, I made an oath to the Lord and told him, ‘I won’t execute you with a sword.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But don’t let him off unpunished, since you’re a wise man and you’ll know what you need to do to him. Find a way that he dies in his old age by shedding his blood.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, David died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried in the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David had reigned over Israel for 40 years. He reigned in Hebron for seven years and in Jerusalem for 33 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon then assumed his father David’s throne, and his kingdom was firmly established.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later, Haggith’s son Adonijah approached Solomon’s mother. “Are you here on a peaceful mission?” she asked.
“Yes,” he replied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I have something to ask you about.”
“Talk,” she told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So he replied, “You know that the kingdom should have come to me, and that everyone in Israel intended to place me as the next king. However, the kingdom has turned around and now belongs to my brother, because it went to him from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So now I’m asking one thing from you. Don’t refuse me.”
“Talk,” she told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he asked her, “Please talk to King Solomon for me, since he won’t refuse you. Ask him to give me Abishag the Shunammite as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Very well,” Bathsheba replied. “I’ll talk to the king for you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Bathsheba went to talk to King Solomon for Adonijah. The king rose to meet her, bowed to her, and sat down on his throne. He ordered a throne be set in place for his mother. She sat on a throne to his right
speaker: Narrator

text:
and told him, “I would like to make a minor request of you. Please don’t refuse me.”
“What is your request, mother?” the king asked her. “I won’t turn you down.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she asked him, “Give Abishag the Shunammite to your brother Adonijah as a wife.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Solomon replied to his mother, “Why are you asking Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? Why not ask me to give up the kingdom for him, since he’s my older brother, and why not ask for Abiathar the priest, and for Zeruiah’s son Joab?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Solomon took this oath in the name of the Lord: “May God do so to me, and more besides, if Adonijah hasn’t endangered his life by bringing up this subject.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, as the Lord lives, who has established me and set me on the throne of my father David, and who has established a dynasty, just like he promised, Adonijah will surely be executed today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Solomon sent for Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, who attacked and killed Adonijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also told Abiathar the priest, “Go home to Anathoth. You deserve to die, but I won’t kill you today, because you carried the ark of the Lord God before my father David and because you shared all the troubles that my father went through.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon fired Abiathar as the Lord’s priest, thus fulfilling the promise that the Lord had spoken in Shiloh concerning Eli’s household.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab learned what had happened, he ran to the Lord’s tent and grabbed hold of the horns of the altar, since Joab had supported Adonijah (though he had not supported Absalom).
speaker: Narrator

text:
Somebody informed King Solomon, “Joab just ran to the Lord’s tent and now he’s standing beside the altar!”
But Solomon ordered Jehoiada’s son Benaiah, “Go kill him!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Benaiah went into the Lord’s tent and told Joab, “The king orders you to come out!”
“No,” Joab said, “I’d rather die here!”
So Benaiah went and informed the king, “This is how Joab answered me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king replied to him, “Do just what he asked. Kill him and bury him so that you may remove from me and from my father’s household the guilt that Joab shed needlessly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will repay him for his bloodshed because, without my father David’s consent he attacked and murdered two men more righteous and better than he, Ner’s son Abner, the commander of Israel’s army and Jether’s son Amasa, commander of Judah’s army.
speaker: Narrator

text: May their blood be repaid to Joab and to his descendants forever, and may there be peace shown from the Lord forever to David, to his descendants, to his household, and to his throne.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah then approached Joab, attacked him, killed him, and had him buried at Joab’s home in the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king appointed Jehoiada’s son Benaiah in charge of the army to replace Joab and also appointed Zadok the priest to replace Abiathar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king sent for Shimei and told him, “Build yourself a house in Jerusalem and live there, but don’t go anywhere from there.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you ever leave and cross the Kidron Brook, you can be sure that you’ll die. You’ll be responsible for your own death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei replied to the king, “What your majesty has decreed is acceptable to me. I’ll do what you’ve said.” So Shimei lived in Jerusalem for quite some time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But three years later, two of Shimei’s servants escaped to Maacah’s son Achish, the king of Gath.
Somebody told Shimei, “Look! Your servants went to Gath!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Shimei got up, saddled a donkey, and traveled to Gath to find his servants. He found them and brought them back from Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Solomon found out that Shimei had left Jerusalem, gone to Gath, and had returned,
speaker: Narrator

text: so the king sent for Shimei and asked him, “Didn’t I make a promise to the Lord and warn you, ‘The day you leave and go anywhere else, you can be sure you’ll die’? And you told me, ‘What your majesty has decreed is acceptable to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: So why haven’t you kept the oath you made to the Lord, and why didn’t you obey my personal order to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also reminded Shimei, “You know all the evil things that you admit you did to my father David. Therefore the Lord is going to repay you for all of your evil.
speaker: Narrator

text: But King Solomon will be blessed, and David’s throne will be established in the presence of the Lord forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king gave orders to Jehoiada’s son Benaiah to go out, attack Shimei, and kill him. That is how the kingdom was established under Solomon’s control.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Solomon intermarried with the family of Pharaoh, the king of Egypt by taking his daughter and bringing her to the City of David to live until he had completed building his own palace, the Lord’s Temple, and the wall around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people were sacrificing at various high places because the Temple had not yet been built and dedicated to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon loved the Lord, and lived according to the statutes that his father David obeyed, except that he sacrificed and burned offerings at the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king used to go to Gibeon to sacrifice, since there was a famous high place there, where Solomon once offered 1,000 burnt offerings on that altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord appeared to Solomon one night in a dream and told him, “Ask me for whatever you want and I’ll give it to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Solomon said:
“You have demonstrated abundant gracious love to your servant David, my father, as he lived in your presence truthfully, righteously, and uprightly in his heart. In addition, you have kept on showing this abundant gracious love by giving him a son to sit on his throne today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now, Lord my God, you have set me as king to replace my father David, but I’m still young. I don’t have any leadership skills.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your servant lives in the midst of your people that you have chosen, a great people that is too numerous to be counted.
speaker: Narrator

text: So give your servant an understanding mind to govern your people, so I can discern between good and evil. Otherwise, how will I be able to govern this great people of yours?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord was pleased that Solomon had asked for this,
speaker: Narrator

text:
so God told him:
“Because you asked for this, and you didn’t ask for a long life for yourself, and you didn’t ask for the lives of your enemies, but instead you’ve asked for discernment so you can understand how to govern,
speaker: Narrator

text: look how I’m going to do precisely what you asked. I’m giving you a wise and discerning mind, so that there will have been no one like you before you and no one will arise after you like you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I’m also giving you what you haven’t requested: both riches and honor, so that no other king will be comparable to you during your lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: If you will live life my way, keeping my statutes and my commands, just like your father David did, I’ll also increase the length of your life.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon woke up and realized that he had dreamed a dream. Then he went back to Jerusalem, stood before the ark of the Lord’s covenant, offered burnt offerings and peace offerings, and threw a party for all of his servants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, two prostitutes approached the king and requested an audience with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: One woman said, “Your majesty, this woman and I live in the same house. I gave birth to a child while she was in the house.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three days later, this woman also gave birth. We lived alone there. There was nobody else with us in the house. It was just the two of us.
speaker: Narrator

text: This woman’s son died overnight because she laid on top of him.
speaker: Narrator

text: She got up in the middle of the night, took my son from me while your servant was asleep, and laid him to her breast after laying her dead son next to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next morning, I got up to nurse my son, and he was dead. But when I examined him carefully in the light of day, he turned out not to be my son whom I had borne!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Not so,” claimed the other woman. “The living child is my son, and the dead one is yours.”
But the first woman said, “Not so! The dead child is your son and the living one is my son.” This is what they testified before the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king said, “One of them claims, ‘This living son is mine, and your son is the dead one’ and the other claims ‘No. Your son is the dead one and my son is the living one.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Somebody get me a sword.” So they brought a sword to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Divide the living child in two!” he ordered. “Give half to the one and half to the other.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The woman whose child was still alive cried out to the king, because her heart yearned for her son. “Oh no, your majesty!” she said. “Give her the living child. Please don’t kill him.”
But the other woman said, “Cut him in half! That way, he’ll belong to neither one of us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king announced his decision: “Give the living child to the first woman. Don’t kill him. She is his mother.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When this decision that the king had handed down was announced, everybody in Israel was amazed at the king, because they all saw that God’s wisdom was in him, enabling him to administer justice.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so King Solomon ruled over all of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here’s a list of his officials: Zadok’s son Azariah was priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shisha’s sons Elihoreph and Ahijah were his secretaries, Ahilud’s son Jehoshaphat was recorder,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah commanded the army, Zadok and Abiathar served as priests,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan’s son Azariah supervised the governors, Nathan’s son Zabud the priest was the king’s counselor,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahishar supervised palace matters, and Abda’s son Adoniram supervised conscripted labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also appointed twelve governors over all of Israel, each of whom were responsible for providing one month’s food provisions to the king and to his administration during each year.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here’s a list of their names: Ben-hur from the hill country of Ephraim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-deker in Makaz, Shaalbim and Beth-shemesh and Elonbeth-hanan;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-hesed served in Arubboth (where he supervised Socoh and all of the territory of Hepher);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-abinadab supervised the Dor heights (Solomon’s daughter Taphath was his wife);
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahilud’s son Baana served Taanach, Megiddo, and all of Beth-shean near Zarethan below Jezreel, including from Beth-shean to Abel-meholah as far as the other side of Jokmeam;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-geber in Ramoth-gilead, including the towns that belonged to Manasseh’s descendant Jair that are in Gilead;
speaker: Narrator

text: Iddo’s son Ahinadab served in Mahanaim;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahimaaz served in Naphtali (he was married to Solomon’s daughter Basemath);
speaker: Narrator

text: Hushai’s son Baana served in Asher and Bealoth;
speaker: Narrator

text: Paruah’s son Jehoshaphat served in Issachar;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ela’s son Shimei served in Benjamin;
speaker: Narrator

text: and Uri’s son Geber served in the territory of Gilead, the territory formerly ruled by King Sihon of the Amorites and King Og of Bashan (he was the only governor over that territory).
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah and Israel became as numerous as the sand on the seashore. They enjoyed abundance, and ate, drank, and rejoiced regularly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon ruled over all the kingdoms from the Euphrates River to the territory of the Philistines and south to the border of Egypt. They brought tribute and served Solomon throughout his lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s daily provisions were 30 kors of fine flour, 60 kors of meal,
speaker: Narrator

text: ten fattened oxen, 20 pasture-fed cattle, 100 sheep, as well as deer, gazelles, roebucks, and domestic poultry.
speaker: Narrator

text: He ruled over everything west of the Euphrates River from Tiphsah to Gaza, over all of the kings west of the Euphrates River, and he enjoyed peace on all sides around him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah and Israel lived safely, and everyone enjoyed their own vine and fig tree from Dan to Beer-sheba through all of Solomon’s life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon owned 40,000 stalls for the horses that drove his chariots, and he employed 12,000 men to drive them.
speaker: Narrator

text: His officers supplied provisions for King Solomon and for everyone who visited King Solomon’s palace, each in their respective month of service responsibility. Nothing ever ran out.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also provided barley and straw for the horses and camels to their respective locations, each consistent with their responsibilities.
speaker: Narrator

text: God gave Solomon wisdom and great discernment. His insights were as numerous as sand on the seashore.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon was wiser than any of the eastern leaders and wiser than anyone in Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He was wiser than anyone of his day—wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, Heman, and wiser than Mahol’s sons Calcol and Darda.
His reputation was known throughout the surrounding nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon wrote 3,000 proverbs and 1,005 songs.
speaker: Narrator

text: He described trees—everything from cedars that grow in Lebanon to hyssop that grows on a garden wall. He described animals, birds, reptiles, and fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: People came from everywhere to hear Solomon’s advice. Every king on the earth heard of his wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Hiram of Tyre sent his servants to Solomon when he learned that Solomon had been anointed king to replace his father, because Hiram had been David’s lifelong friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon sent this message to Hiram:
speaker: Narrator

text: “You know that my father David was unable to build a temple dedicated to the Lord his God because he was busy fighting wars all around him until the Lord defeated his enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the Lord has given me rest all around, since I have neither foreign adversaries nor domestic crises.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now I’m planning to build a temple dedicated to the Lord my God, just as the Lord told my father when he said, ‘Your son, whom I will set on your throne to replace you, will build the Temple dedicated to me.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore please order that cedars of Lebanon be cut for me. My servants will work with your servants, and I will pay your servants whatever wages you set, because you know there is no one among us who knows how to cut timber like the Sidonians do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Hiram received the message from Solomon, he became so ecstatic that he exclaimed, “Blessed be the Lord today, who has given David a wise son to rule this great people!” Then he sent this message to Solomon:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have read the letter that you sent me. I’ll do what you’ve asked about the cedar and cypress timber.
speaker: Narrator

text: My servants will transport them from Lebanon to the sea, where we’ll make them into rafts and float them by sea to the port that you tell me to send them. We’ll have them prepared for transport there and then you can carry them from there. You can meet my needs by providing provisions for my household.”
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s how Hiram came to provide Solomon as much cedar and cypress timber as he needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: In return, Solomon paid Hiram 20,000 kors of wheat as food for his household, and 20 kors of beaten oil. Solomon provided this amount every year during the construction.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord continued giving Solomon wisdom, just as he had promised, and Hiram and Solomon entered into a peace treaty between themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon conscripted laborers from throughout Israel. The work force numbered 30,000 men.
speaker: Narrator

text: He sent 10,000 men to Lebanon in shifts lasting one month. They worked one month in Lebanon for every two months they worked at home. Adoniram was placed in charge of the conscripted labor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also employed 70,000 heavy-lift workers and 80,000 stonecutters in the hill country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also employed 3,300 officials to supervise the work and to manage the people employed in the construction.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king specified that large, expensive stones be quarried so the foundation of the Temple could be laid with cut stones.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, Solomon’s builders worked with Hiram’s builders, accompanied by the Gebalites, to quarry the stone and to prepare the timber and other stone for the Temple’s construction.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the month of Ziv, which was the second month of the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, 480 years after the Israelis left the land of Egypt, Solomon began to build the Lord’s Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Temple for the Lord that Solomon was building was 60 cubits long and 20 cubits wide.
speaker: Narrator

text: A portico extended in front of the Temple for 20 cubits outward, corresponding to the width of the Temple. Along the front of the Temple its depth was ten cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also constructed windows in the Temple with specially designed frames.
speaker: Narrator

text: Against the wall of the Temple he built a series of rooms that encompassed the exterior of the Temple walls around the inner sanctuary. He built these side chambers all around the building.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lower structures were five cubits wide, the middle structures were six cubits wide and the third structures were seven cubits wide. Offsets were placed all around the Temple so that beams would not protrude through the walls of the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Temple was constructed of stone precut at the quarry so that no hammer, axe, or any other iron implement would be heard in the Temple while it was being built.
speaker: Narrator

text: A passageway to the side chamber was constructed on the south side of the Temple by which people could ascend winding stairs to the middle story, then from there to the third story.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Solomon built the Temple and finished it, he covered the Temple with beams and planks made of cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: He constructed this structure to adjoin the entire Temple, five cubits high, and fastened it to the Temple with cedar timbers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then this message from the Lord came to Solomon:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Concerning this Temple that you’re building, if you live your life according to my statutes, carry out my ordinances, and keep all of my commands, and live according to them, then I will do what I promised to your father David.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will reside among the Israelis and will never abandon my people Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon kept on building the Temple and finished it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he built the inside walls of the Temple, lining them from floor to ceiling with cedar boards, and overlaying the Temple floor with boards made of cypress wood.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lined 20 cubits of the rear part of the Temple from floor to ceiling with cedar boards specially constructed for the inside to serve as the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the main nave in the front was 40 cubits long.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cedar carvings in the form of gourds and blooming flowers covered the entire interior of the Temple so that no stone could be seen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also prepared an inner sanctuary within the Temple where the Lord’s Ark of the Covenant was placed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inner sanctuary was 20 cubits long, 20 cubits wide, and 20 cubits high, and overlaid with pure gold. The altar was also overlaid with cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon overlaid the inside of the Temple with pure gold, fastened gold chains across the front of the inner sanctuary, and overlaid it with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: He finished the Temple by overlaying it entirely with gold, including overlaying with gold the whole altar that was by the inner sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Inside the inner sanctuary Solomon placed two cherubim crafted from olive wood, each ten cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each wing of one cherub was five cubits long, and each wing of the other cherub was five cubits long, so that the distance from the end of one wing to the end of the other wing was ten cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each cherub was ten cubits high, and both were of the same size and shape,
speaker: Narrator

text: the height of one cherub being ten cubits, as was the height of the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon placed the cherubim in the middle of the inner sanctuary, with their wings spread in such a way that the wing of one was touching the one wall and the opposite wing of the other cherub was touching the opposite wall. Furthermore, their wings in the center of the wall were touching each other wing-to-wing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each cherub was overlaid with gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also inlaid all the inner walls of the Temple—both the inner and outer sanctuaries—with carved engravings of cherubim, palm trees, and blooming flowers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also overlaid the floor of the Temple with gold in both the inner and outer sanctuaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also provided doors, lintels, and five-sided doorposts for the entrance to the inner sanctuary.
speaker: Narrator

text: He installed two doors made of olive wood, inlaying them with carvings of cherubim, palm trees, and blooming flowers, and overlaying them with gold. Then he added more gold to cover the cherubim and palm trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also provided four-sided doorposts made of cypress wood for the entrance to the outer sanctuary,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with two doors of cypress wood, one door of which had two leaves that turned on hinges, as did the other door, which also had two leaves that turned on hinges.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon also inlaid the doors with cherubim, palm trees, and blooming flowers. He overlaid them with gold that was carefully applied on the engraved work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He constructed the inner court with three rows of precut stone and a row of cedar beams.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foundation for the Lord’s Temple was laid in the month of Ziv during the fourth year of Solomon’s reign,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Temple was completely finished according to its plans and specifications in the eighth month of the eleventh year of Solomon’s reign, that is, during the month of Bul. It took about seven years to build.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Solomon took thirteen years to build his own palace, and finally finished it.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built his own palace out of timber supplied from the forest of Lebanon. It was 100 cubits long, 50 cubits wide, 20 cubits tall, and was constructed on four rows of cedar pillars, with cedar beams interlocking the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 45 pillars paneled with cedar above the side chambers, with rows of fifteen pillars,
speaker: Narrator

text: with three rows of framed windows facing each other in three ranks.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the doorways and doorposts had rectangular frames, with the doorways facing each other in three tiers.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was also a hall of pillars 50 cubits long and 30 cubits wide, and a porch in front with pillars, and a canopy in front of the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: He constructed the Judgment Hall for the throne room where he would be ruling, paneling it with cedar from floor to ceiling.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon’s personal dwelling quarters, a separate court behind the hall, was of similar workmanship. Solomon also built a house similar to this for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom Solomon had married.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these were made with expensive stones, pre-cut according to specifications, hand-sawed inside and out from the foundation to the coping, including from inside to the great court.
speaker: Narrator

text: The foundation was made of expensive stone, including large stones ten cubits long and stones eight cubits long.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above these were expensive stones cut according to specifications, and cedar.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the great court was surrounded by three rows of cut stone, along with a row of cedar beams, just like the inner court of the Lord’s Temple and the porch surrounding the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon sent for Hiram from Tyre,
speaker: Narrator

text: the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, whose father was from Tyre. A bronze worker, he was wise, knowledgeable, and was skilled in all sorts of bronze working. He went to King Solomon and did all of his work.
speaker: Narrator

text: He fashioned two bronze pillars, each one eighteen cubits high, with a circumference of twelve cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also crafted two capitals of cast bronze and set them on top of the pillars. The height of one capital was five cubits, and the height of the other capital was five cubits.
speaker: Narrator

text: A network of latticework on top of the pillars was inlaid with ornamental wreaths and chains, the top of each pillar containing seven groups of ornamental structures.
speaker: Narrator

text: The pillars contained two rows of ornaments shaped like pomegranates around the latticework covering the top of each pillar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The capitals on top of each pillar above the rounded latticework contained four cubits of lily designs,
speaker: Narrator

text: with the capitals on the two pillars covered by 200 pomegranates in rows around both the capitals above and adjoining the rounded latticework.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s how he designed the pillars at the portico of the sanctuary. When he set up the right pillar, he named it Jachin. When he set up the left pillar, he named it Boaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The work on the pillars was finished with a lily design on top of the pillars.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram also made a sea of cast metal ten cubits from brim to brim, circular in shape and five cubits and 30 cubits in its inner circumference.
speaker: Narrator

text: Under the brim, completely encircling it, were two rows of gourds inlaid as part of the original casting, ten to a cubit.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sea stood on top of twelve oxen. Three faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east. The sea was set on top of them, and their hind parts faced the center.
speaker: Narrator

text: The reservoir, which held about 2,000 baths, stood about a handbreadth thick, and its rim looked like the brim of a cup or of a lily blossom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram also made ten bronze water carts. Each one was four cubits wide, four cubits long, and three cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: The carts were designed with borders between cross-pieces,
speaker: Narrator

text: and on the borders between the cross-pieces were lions, oxen, and cherubim. A pedestal was placed above the cross-pieces, and beneath the lions and oxen there were wreaths hanging down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each cart had four bronze wheels equipped with bronze axles with four support feet. Beneath the basin were cast support structures made like wreaths on each side.
speaker: Narrator

text: The opening to each water cart inside the crown on top was one cubit wide, with engravings on the opening. The borders to the frames surrounding the opening were square, not round.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four wheels were placed underneath the borders, and the axles for the wheels were on the stand. Each wheel stood one and a half cubits high.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wheels resembled those of a chariot, with their axles, rims, spokes, and hubs made of cast bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: Four supports stood at the four corners of each cart, built into the carts themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: On top of each stand was a circular structure one half of one cubit high, with its braces and support frames integral with it, forming a single piece.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram engraved ornamental cherubim, lions, and palm trees on the surfaces of the supports and frames wherever there was space to do so, and encircled the artwork with wreaths.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made ten identical water carts by using the same plans, castings, and shapes for all of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram also fashioned ten bronze basins, each holding about 40 baths, each basin measuring four cubits in diameter, with one basin for each stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: He set five of the stands on the right side of the Temple and five on the left side of the Temple. He set the bronze sea on the right side of the Temple eastward facing the south.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram also made the basins, shovels, and bowls to complete the work that he performed for King Solomon in the Lord’s Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: including the two pillars and the bowls for the capitals that stood on top of the two pillars, along with the two lattices that covered the two bowls of the capitals that stood on top of the pillars,
speaker: Narrator

text: plus the 400 pomegranates for the two lattices (that is, the two rows of pomegranates for each lattice to cover the two bowls of the capitals that stood on top of the pillars),
speaker: Narrator

text: the ten stands with the ten basins on the stands,
speaker: Narrator

text: the single bronze sea and the twelve oxen that stood under the sea,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the pots, shovels, and bowls—all of these utensils that Hiram made for King Solomon for the Lord’s Temple were made from polished bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king had them cast in the clay ground between Succoth and Zarethan in the Jordan plain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon never inventoried the weight of the bronze used, because there were too many utensils, so the weight of the bronze used was never ascertained.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon made all the furnishings that were placed in the Lord’s Temple, including the golden altar and the golden table on which the bread of the Presence was placed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with the lamp stands (five on the right side and five on the left in front of the inner sanctuary), all made of pure gold, as well as the flower blossoms, lamps, and tongs of gold,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the cups, snuffers, bowls, spoons, and the fire pans, all made of pure gold, and hinges for the doors of the inner sanctuary, the Most Holy Place, and for the gates of the Temple that led to the nave, also of gold.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus all the work that King Solomon performed in the Lord’s Temple was finished. Then Solomon brought in the articles that had been dedicated by his father David, including silver, gold, and other utensils, and he placed them into storage in the treasuries of the Lord’s Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon gathered together the elders of Israel, including all the heads of the tribes and the leaders of the ancestral households of the Israelis, to meet with him in Jerusalem so they could bring up the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from Zion, the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the men gathered together to meet with King Solomon at the Festival of Tents in the month Ethanim, the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Elders of Israel showed up, and the priests picked up the ark
speaker: Narrator

text: and brought it, the Tent of Meeting, and all the holy implements that were in the tent. The priests and descendants of Levi carried them up to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Solomon and the entire congregation of Israel that had assembled to be with him stood in front of the ark, sacrificing so many sheep and oxen that they were neither counted nor inventoried.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, the priests brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord to the place prepared for it, into the inner sanctuary of the Temple, under the wings of the cherubim in the Most Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: The wings of the cherubim spread over the resting place for the ark, so that the cherubim made a covering over the ark and its poles when viewed from above.
speaker: Narrator

text: The poles extended so far that their ends could be seen from the Holy Place in front of the inner sanctuary, but they could not be seen from outside. They remain there to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ark was empty except for the two stone tablets that Moses had placed there at Horeb when the Lord had made a covenant with the Israelis after they had come out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the priests left the Holy Place after setting the ark in place, the cloud filled the Lord’s Temple
speaker: Narrator

text: so that the priests could not stand to minister because of the cloud, since the glory of the Lord filled the Lord’s Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon said, “The Lord has said that he lives shrouded in darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now I have been constructing a magnificent Temple dedicated to you that will serve as a place for you to inhabit forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king turned to face the entire congregation of Israel while the congregation of Israel remained standing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Solomon prayed:
“Blessed is the Lord God of Israel, who made a commitment to my father David and then personally fulfilled what he had promised when he said:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘From the day I brought out my people Israel from Egypt I never chose a city from all the tribes of Israel to build a temple where my name might reside. I have chosen David to be over my people Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “My father David wanted to build a temple for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord told my father David:
‘Therefore, since you determined to build a temple for my name, you acted well, because it was your choice to do so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, you are not to build the Temple, but your son who will be born to you is to build a temple for my name.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord has brought to fulfillment what he promised, and now here I stand, having succeeded my father David to sit on the throne of Israel, as the Lord promised. I have built the Temple for the name of the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have placed there the ark in which the covenant is stored that the Lord made with our ancestors when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Solomon took his place in front of the Lord’s altar in the presence of the entire congregation of Israel, spread out his hands toward heaven,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and said:
“Lord God of Israel, there is no one like you, God in heaven above or on the earth below, who watches over his covenant, showing gracious love to your servants who live their lives in your presence with all their hearts.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is you, Lord God, who have kept your promise to my father, your servant David, that you made to him. Indeed, you made a commitment to my father David and then personally fulfilled what you had promised today.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore, Lord God of Israel, keep your promise that you made to my father, your servant David, when you said, ‘You will not lack a man to sit on the throne of Israel, if only your descendants will watch their lives, to live in my presence just as you have lived in my presence.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore, God of Israel, may your promise that you made to your servant David my father be fulfilled…
speaker: Narrator

text: and yet, will God truly reside on earth? Look! Neither the sky nor the highest heaven can contain you! How much less this Temple that I have built!
speaker: Narrator

text: Pay attention to the prayer of your servant and to his request, Lord my God, and listen to the cry and prayer that your servant is praying in your presence today.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let your eyes always look toward this Temple night and day, toward the location where you have said ‘My name will reside there.’ Listen to the prayer that your servant prays in this direction.
speaker: Narrator

text: Listen to the requests from your servant and from your people Israel as they pray in this direction, listen from the place where you reside in heaven, then hear and forgive.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a man should sin against his neighbor and he is required to take an oath, and he then comes to take an oath in front of your altar in this Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then listen in heaven, act, and judge your servants, condemning the wicked by bringing back to him the consequences of his choices and by justifying the righteous by recompensing him according to his righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If your people Israel are defeated in a battle with their enemy because they have sinned against you, when they return to you and confess to you, pray, and in this Temple they ask you to show grace to them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven, forgive the sin of your people Israel, and return them to the soil that you gave to their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When heaven remains closed, and there is no rain because they have sinned against you, and they pray in the direction of this place, confessing your name and turning from their sin when you afflict them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of your servants and of your people Israel. Indeed, teach them the best way to live and send rain on your land that you have given to your people as an inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a famine comes to the land, or if plant diseases, mildew, locust, or grasshoppers appear, or if their enemies attack them in their settlements of the land, no matter what the epidemic or illness is,
speaker: Narrator

text: whatever prayer or request is made, no matter whether it’s made by a single man or by all of your people Israel, each praying out of his own hurting heart and anguish and stretching out his hands toward this Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear from heaven, the place where you reside, and forgive, repaying each person according to all of his ways, since you know their hearts—for you alone know the hearts of all human beings—
speaker: Narrator

text: so they will fear you every day and live on the surface of the land that you have given to our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now concerning the foreigner who is not from your people Israel, when he comes from a land far away for the sake of your name
speaker: Narrator

text: (for people will hear of your great name, your mighty acts, and your obvious power), when he comes and prays facing this Temple,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear in heaven where you reside, and do whatever the foreigner asks of you, so that all the people of the earth may know your name, fear you as do your people Israel, and so they may know that this Temple that I have built is called by your name.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When your people go out to war against their enemies, no matter what way you send them, and they pray to the Lord in the direction of the city that you have chosen and in the direction of the Temple that I have built for your name,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear their prayer and their request in heaven, and fight for their cause.
speaker: Narrator

text: “When they sin against you—because there isn’t a single human being who doesn’t sin—and you become angry with them and deliver them over to their enemy, who takes them away captive to the land that belongs to their enemy, whether near or far away,
speaker: Narrator

text: if they turn their hearts back to you in the land where they have been taken captive, repent, and pray to you—even if they do so in the land of their captivity—confessing, ‘We have sinned, we have committed abominations, and practiced wickedness,’
speaker: Narrator

text: if they return to you with all of their heart and with all of their soul in the land of their enemies who have taken them captive, as they pray to you in the direction of their land that you have given to their ancestors and to the city that you have chosen, and to the Temple that I have built for your name,
speaker: Narrator

text: then hear their prayer and requests in heaven, where you reside, and fight for their cause,
speaker: Narrator

text:
forgiving your people who have sinned against you, along with their transgressions by which they have transgressed against you.
“Show your compassion in the presence of those who have taken them captive, so they may show compassion on them,
speaker: Narrator

text: since they are your people and your heritage, which you brought out of Egypt, from an iron fire furnace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this so your eyes may remain open to the requests of your servant and to the requests of your people’s prayers, to listen to them whenever they call out to you,
speaker: Narrator

text: because you have separated them to yourself as your heritage from all the people of the earth, as you spoke through your servant Moses when you brought our ancestors out of Egypt, Lord God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Solomon had completed saying this entire prayer to the Lord, he got up from kneeling with his hands spread out toward heaven in the presence of the Lord’s altar,
speaker: Narrator

text: stood up, and blessed all of the assembly of Israel in a loud voice. He said:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Blessed is the Lord, who has given security to his people Israel, just as he promised. Not one of his promises has failed to come about that he gave through his servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: May the Lord our God be with us, just as he was with our ancestors. May he never leave us or abandon us,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that he may turn our hearts toward him, so that we may live life his way, keeping his commands, statutes, and ordinances that he gave to our ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: And may what I’ve had to say to the Lord remain with the Lord our God both day and night, so that he may defend the cause of his servant and the cause of his people Israel, as the need of the day may require it,
speaker: Narrator

text: so that, in turn, all the people of the earth may know that the Lord is God—there is no one else.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now let your heart be completely devoted to the Lord our God, to live according to his statutes and to keep his commands, as we are doing today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king and all of Israel with him offered sacrifices to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Solomon offered peace offerings to the Lord consisting of 22,000 oxen and 120,000 sheep. So the king and all the Israelis dedicated the Lord’s Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: That same day, the king consecrated the middle court that stood in front of the Lord’s Temple, because that was where he offered burnt offerings, grain offerings, and fat from the peace offerings and because the bronze altar that was in the Lord’s presence was too small to hold the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and fat from the peace offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon observed the Festival of Tents at that time, as did all of Israel with him. A large assembly came up from as far away as Lebo-hamath and the Wadi of Egypt to appear in the presence of the Lord our God, not just for seven days, but for seven days after that, a total of fourteen days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following day, Solomon sent the people away as they blessed the king. Then they went back to their tents, rejoicing and glad for all the good things that the Lord had done for his servant David and to his people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, after Solomon had finished building the Lord’s Temple, the royal palace, and everything else that Solomon wanted to do,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Lord appeared to Solomon for a second time, just as he had appeared to him at Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord told him:
“I’ve heard your prayer and your request that you made to me. I have consecrated this Temple that you have built by placing my name there forever. My eyes and my heart will be there continuously.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now as for you, if you commune with me like your father did, with an upright heart of integrity and doing everything that I’ve commanded you and keeping my statutes and ordinances,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I’ll make your royal throne secure forever, just as I agreed to do so for your father David when I said, ‘You are to not lack a man on the throne of Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you or your descendants abandon me, and do not keep my commandments and statutes that I have given to you, and if you go away, serve other gods, and worship them,
speaker: Narrator

text: then I will eliminate Israel from the land that I gave them and from the Temple that I’ve consecrated for my name. I will throw them out of my sight, and Israel will become the butt of jokes and a means of ridicule among people worldwide!
speaker: Narrator

text: “This Temple will become a pile of ruins. Everyone who passes by it will be so astounded that they will ask, ‘Why did the Lord do this to this land and to this Temple?’
speaker: Narrator

text: They will answer, ‘Because they abandoned the Lord their God, who brought their ancestors out of the land of Egypt, and they adopted other gods and served them. That’s why the Lord has brought all of this disaster on them.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: It took 20 years for Solomon to finish working on the two houses—the Lord’s Temple and the royal palace—
speaker: Narrator

text: after which King Solomon gave Hiram 20 cities in the land of Galilee, because King Hiram of Tyre had provided Solomon with as much cedar, cypress timber, and gold as he wanted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hiram came out from Tyre to see the cities that Solomon had given him, but he wasn’t happy with them,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he asked him, “What are these cities that you have given to me, my brother?” That’s why these cities were named “the land of Cabal” to this day.
speaker: Narrator
