speaker: Narrator

text: Everyone in Israel will mourn for him and will bury him, because he alone from Jeroboam’s family will receive a decent burial, because something good was observed in him with respect to the Lord God of Israel out of all the household of Jeroboam!
speaker: Narrator

text: “In addition to this, the Lord will raise up for himself a king over Israel who will eliminate Jeroboam’s dynasty, starting today and from now on.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will attack Israel, and Israel will shake like a reed shakes in a river current! He will uproot Israel from this good land that he gave to their ancestors and he will scatter them beyond the Euphrates River, because they erected their Asherim and provoked the Lord to become angry!
speaker: Narrator

text: He will give up Israel because of Jeroboam’s sins that he committed and by which Jeroboam caused Israel to sin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Jeroboam’s wife got up and left for Tirzah. As soon as she set foot over the threshold of the house, the child died.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of Israel mourned him at his burial, just as the Lord had said when he spoke through Ahijah the prophet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as for the rest of Jeroboam’s accomplishments, including how he waged war and how he reigned, you may read about them in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam reigned for 22 years and then died, as had his ancestors, and his son Nadab reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, Solomon’s son Rehoboam reigned in Judah. Rehoboam was 41 years old when he became king, and he reigned for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city where the Lord had chosen from all the tribes of Israel to place his Name. His mother was an Ammonite named Naamah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah practiced what the Lord considered to be evil. They did more to provoke him to jealousy than their ancestors had ever done by committing the sins that they committed.
speaker: Narrator

text: They erected high places, sacred pillars, and Asherim for themselves on every high hill and under every green tree.
speaker: Narrator

text: They even maintained male shrine prostitutes throughout the land, and imitated every detestable practice that the nations practiced whom the Lord had expelled in front of the Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: As a result, during the fifth year of the reign of King Rehoboam, King Shishak of Egypt invaded and attacked Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stripped the Lord’s Temple and the royal palace of their treasures. He took everything, even the gold shields that Solomon had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Rehoboam made shields out of bronze to take their place, and then committed them to the care and custody of the commanders of those who guarded the entrance to the royal palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whenever the king entered the Lord’s Temple, the guards would carry them to and from the guard’s quarters.
speaker: Narrator

text: As to the rest of Rehoboam’s accomplishments, and everything else that he undertook, they are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, aren’t they?
speaker: Narrator

text: There was continual warfare between Rehoboam and Jeroboam,
speaker: Narrator

text: but eventually Rehoboam died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David. His mother’s name had been Naamah the Ammonite, and his son Abijah became king to replace him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abijah reigned over Judah starting in the eighteenth year of Nebat’s son Jeroboam’s reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned for three years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Maacah, the daughter of Abishalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He practiced the same sins that his father committed before he was born. Unlike his ancestor David, his heart never became devoted to the Lord his God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, for the sake of David, the Lord his God maintained a lamp for David in Jerusalem by raising up his son after him so that Jerusalem would be established,
speaker: Narrator

text: because David had practiced what the Lord considered to be right. He never avoided anything that the Lord had commanded him during his entire lifetime, except for the case of Uriah the Hittite.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was continual military conflict between Rehoboam and Jeroboam throughout his entire lifetime.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Abijah’s accomplishments, including everything he undertook, are written in the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not? And a state of war continued to exist between Abijah and Jeroboam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Abijah died, as did his ancestors, and he was buried in the City of David. His son Asa succeeded him as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa began to reign as Judah’s king during the twentieth year of the reign of Jeroboam as king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned 41 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Maacah, the daughter of Abishalom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa practiced what the Lord considered to be right, just like his ancestor David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also removed the male cult prostitutes from the land and destroyed all the idols that his ancestors had made.
speaker: Narrator

text: He removed his mother Maacah from her position as Queen Mother because she had made a detestable image dedicated to Asherah. Asa cut down his mother’s idol, crushed it, and burned it at the Kidron Brook.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the high places were not removed, even though Asa’s heart was blameless toward the Lord all of his life.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa brought into the Lord’s Temple the things that his father had dedicated, as well as his own dedicated gifts such as silver, gold, and temple service implements.
speaker: Narrator

text: A state of continual military unrest existed between Asa and King Baasha of Israel throughout their lifetimes.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Baasha of Israel invaded Judah and interdicted Ramah by building fortifications around it so no one could enter or leave to join King Asa of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Asa removed all the silver and gold from the treasuries of the Lord’s Temple and from his royal palace, placed them into the care of some servants, and then sent them to Tabrimmon’s son King Ben-hadad of Aram, the grandson of Hezion, who lived in Damascus.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let’s make a treaty between you and me,” he said, “just like the one between my father and your father. Notice that I’ve sent you silver and gold to break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel, so he’ll retreat from his attack on me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So King Ben-hadad did just what King Asa had asked: he sent his commanding officers to attack the cities of Israel, conquering Ijon, Dan, Abel-beth-maacah, all of Chinneroth, and the territory of Naphtali.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Baasha learned of this, he stopped fortifying Ramah and remained in Tirzah,
speaker: Narrator

text: so King Asa published a proclamation throughout Judah (no one was left out) and they carried away the stones and timber with which Baasha had been fortifying Judah. King Asa used them to fortify Geba in Benjamin and Mizpah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Asa’s accomplishments, his strength, everything that he undertook, and the cities that he fortified are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not? However, as he approached old age, he became diseased in his feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Asa died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried with his ancestors in the City of David, his ancestor. His son Jehoshaphat reigned in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeroboam’s son Nadab became king over Israel during the second year of the reign of King Asa over Judah. He reigned over Israel for two years,
speaker: Narrator

text: practicing what the Lord considered to be evil, living the way his father did, committing sins, and leading Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahijah’s son Baasha from the household of Issachar conspired against him and killed Nadab at Gibbethon in Philistia while Nadab and all of Israel were attacking Gibbethon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Baasha killed him during the third year of the reign of King Asa of Judah and took Nadab’s place as king.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he was established as king, he killed everyone in the household of Jeroboam. He left not even one single person alive. He destroyed them completely, just as the Lord had spoken through his servant Ahijah the Shilonite,
speaker: Narrator

text: because of the sins that Jeroboam had committed, and because he led Israel into sin, provoking the Lord God of Israel to become angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of Nadab’s accomplishments, including everything he undertook, are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, a state of war continued to exist between Asa and Baasha king of Israel, throughout their reigns.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the third year of the reign of King Asa of Judah, Ahijah’s son Baasha became king over all of Israel. He reigned for 24 years at Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be evil, living like Jeroboam did and leading Israel into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, a message came from the Lord to Hanani’s son Jehu. It was directed to rebuke Baasha, and this is what it said:
speaker: Narrator

text: “I raised you from the dirt to become Commander-in-Chief over my people Israel, but you’ve been living like Jeroboam, you’ve been leading my people Israel into sin, and you’ve been provoking me to anger with their sins.
speaker: Narrator

text: So watch out! I’m going to devour Baasha and his household. I’m going to make your household just like the household of Jeroboam, Nebat’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone from Baasha’s household who dies in the city will be eaten by dogs, and anyone of his who dies in the field the birds of the sky will eat.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of Baasha’s accomplishments, including everything that he undertook, as well as his strengths, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Baasha died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried in Tirzah. His son Elah was installed as king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: In addition, a message from the Lord came through Hanani’s son Jehu the prophet against Baasha and his household, not only because of all of the things that Baasha did that the Lord considered to be evil, including provoking the Lord to anger by what he did and by being like the household of Jeroboam, but also because Baasha had destroyed Jeroboam’s household.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the twenty-sixth year of the reign of King Asa of Judah, Baasha’s son Elah became king over Israel and reigned at Tirzah for two years.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his servant Zimri, who commanded half of his chariot forces, conspired against Elah while he was drinking himself drunk in the home of Arza, who managed the household at Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zimri went inside, attacked him, and killed him in the twenty-seventh year of the reign of King Asa of Judah, and then became king in Elah’s place.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as he had consolidated his reign, he executed the entire household of Baasha. He did not leave a single male alive, including any of Baasha’s relatives or friends.
speaker: Narrator

text: In doing so, Zimri destroyed the entire household of Baasha, in keeping with the message from the Lord that he had spoken against Baasha through Jehu the prophet
speaker: Narrator

text: because of all the sins that Baasha and his son Elah had committed and because of what they did to lead Israel into sin, thus provoking the Lord God of Israel to anger with their idolatry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of Elah’s accomplishments, including everything he undertook, are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: Zimri reigned for seven days at Tirzah during the twenty-seventh year of the reign of King Asa of Judah. At that time, the army was encamped in a siege against Gibbethon of Philistia.
speaker: Narrator

text: The army at the encampment heard this report: “Zimri has conspired against the king and killed him.” So the entire army of Israel made Omri, their commander, king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Omri and the entire army of Israel left from Gibbethon and attacked Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Zimri observed that the city had been captured, he retreated into the king’s palace, set fire to the citadel, and died when the palace burned down around him
speaker: Narrator

text: because of the sins that he committed by doing what the Lord considered to be evil, living like Jeroboam did, and sinning so as to lead Israel into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of Zimri’s accomplishments, including his conspiracy that he carried out, are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: The army of Israel was divided into two parties: half of the army were loyal to Ginath’s son Tibni and wanted to make him king, and half were loyal to Omri.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the army that was loyal to Omri was victorious over Ginath’s son Tibni. Tibni later died and Omri became king.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the thirty-first year of the reign of King Asa of Judah, Omri became king over Israel. He reigned for twelve years, six of them at Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for two talents of silver, fortified the hill, and named the city Samaria after Shemer, the former owner of the hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Omri practiced what the Lord considered to be evil, doing far more evil than anyone who had reigned before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived just like Nebat’s son Jeroboam, and by his sin he led Israel into sin, provoking the Lord God of Israel with their idolatry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of Omri’s accomplishments, including the power that he demonstrated, are recorded in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: So Omri died, as had his ancestors, and he was buried in Samaria. His son Ahab became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Omri’s son Ahab became king over Israel in the thirty-eighth year of King Asa of Judah. He reigned over Israel in Samaria for 22 years.
speaker: Narrator

text: Omri’s son Ahab practiced more of what the Lord considered to be evil than anyone who had lived before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: In fact, as if it were nothing for him to live like Nebat’s son Jeroboam, Ahab married Jezebel, the daughter of King Ethbaal of Sidon. Then he went out to serve Baal and worship him.
speaker: Narrator

text: He built an altar for Baal in a temple for Baal that he constructed in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab also erected an Asherah, doing more to provoke the Lord God of Israel than all of the kings of Israel who had reigned before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was during Ahab’s reign that Hiel the Bethelite rebuilt Jericho. He laid its foundations just as his firstborn son Abiram was dying, and he erected its gates while his youngest son Segub was dying, thus fulfilling the message that the Lord delivered through Nun’s son Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah the foreigner, who was an alien resident from Gilead, told Ahab, “As the Lord God of Israel lives, in whose presence I’m standing, there will be neither dew nor rain these next several years, except when I say so.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, this message came to him from the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Leave here and go into hiding at the Wadi Cherith, where it enters the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be able to drink from that brook, and I’ve commanded some crows to sustain you there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elijah left and did exactly what the Lord had told him to do—he went to live near the Wadi Cherith, where it enters the Jordan River.
speaker: Narrator

text: Crows would bring him bread and meat both in the morning and in the evening, and he would drink from the brook.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after a while, the brook dried up because there had been no rain in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then this message came to him from the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get up, move to Zarephath in Sidon, and stay there. Look! I’ve commanded a widow to sustain you there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he got up and went to Zarephath. As he arrived at the entrance to the city, a widow was there gathering sticks. So he asked her, “Please, may I have some water in a cup so I can have a drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: While she was on her way to get the water, he called out to her, “Would you please also bring me a piece of bread while you’re at it?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “As the Lord your God lives,” she replied, “I don’t have so much as a muffin, just a handful of flour in a bowl and some oil left in a bottle. Now I’m going to find some sticks so I can cook a last meal for my son and for me. Then we’re going to eat it and die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elijah told her, “You can stop being afraid. Go and do what you said, but first make me a muffin and bring it to me. Then make a meal for yourself and for your son,
speaker: Narrator

text: because this is what the Lord God of Israel says: ‘That jar of flour will not run out, nor will that bottle of oil become empty until the very day that the Lord sends rain on the surface of the ground.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she went out and did precisely what Elijah told her to do. As a result, Elijah, the widow, and her son were fed for days.
speaker: Narrator

text: The jar of flour never ran out and the bottle of oil never became empty, just as the Lord had promised through Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sometime later, the son of the woman who owned the house became ill. In fact, his illness became so severe that he died.
speaker: Narrator

text: “What do we have in common, you man of God?” she accused Elijah. “You came to me so you could uncover my guilt! And you’re responsible for the death of my son!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Give me your son,” he replied. Then he took him from her lap, carried him upstairs to the room where he lived, and laid him on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he called out to the Lord and asked him, “Lord my God, have you also brought evil to this dear widow with whom I am living as her guest? Have you caused the death of her son?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he stretched himself three times and cried out to the Lord, “Lord my God, please cause the soul of this little boy to return to him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord listened to Elijah, and the soul of the little boy returned to him, and he revived.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Elijah took the little boy downstairs from the upper chamber back into the main house and delivered him to his mother. “Look,” Elijah told her, “your son is alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The woman responded to Elijah, “Now at last I’ve really learned that you are a man of God and that what you have to say about the Lord is the truth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Quite some time later—three years later!—this message from the Lord came to Elijah: “Go visit Ahab, and I’ll send some rain to the surface of the ground.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elijah went to show himself to Ahab, right when the famine in Samaria was most severe.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab called for Obadiah, his household supervisor. This man, who feared the Lord very much,
speaker: Narrator

text: had taken 100 prophets and had hidden them by fifties in a cave, providing them with food and water when Jezebel was trying to destroy the Lord’s prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab had instructed Obadiah, “Go throughout the land to all of the water springs and to all of the valleys. Maybe we’ll find some grass to keep the horses and mules alive. Also, maybe we won’t have to kill some of our cattle.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they divided the land between them so they could conduct their survey. Ahab went off by himself in one direction and Obadiah went off by himself in the other.
speaker: Narrator

text: While Obadiah was on the road, Elijah met him. Obadiah recognized him and bowed down with his face to the ground. “It’s you, isn’t it, my master Elijah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I am,” he replied. “Go tell your master, ‘Look! Elijah!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Obadiah replied, “What did I do wrong, that you would put me in a position where Ahab would execute me?
speaker: Narrator

text: As surely as the Lord your God lives, there isn’t a nation or kingdom where my master hasn’t tried to find you. Whenever they would say ‘He isn’t here,’ he forced that kingdom or nation to swear that they hadn’t seen you.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now you’re saying ‘Go tell your master, “Elijah is here!”’
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as I’ve left you, the Spirit of the Lord will carry you off to I don’t know where! Then when I go tell Ahab and he can’t find you, he’ll kill me, even though I have been your servant and have feared the Lord since I was young!
speaker: Narrator

text: Hasn’t anyone told you, my master, what I did when Jezebel was killing the Lord’s prophets? I hid 100 of the Lord’s prophets by fifties in a cave and provided food and water for them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now you’re saying, ‘Go tell your master, “Elijah’s here!”’ He’s sure to kill me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elijah promised him, “As the Lord of the Heavenly Armies lives, in whose presence I stand, I will appear to Ahab today.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Obadiah went out to meet Ahab and reported to him. Then Ahab went to meet Elijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Ahab saw Elijah, Ahab asked him, “Is it really you, you destroyer of Israel?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elijah replied, “I’m no destroyer of Israel. But you and your ancestor’s household have been doing that, because you have abandoned the Lord’s commandments and have followed the Baals.
speaker: Narrator

text: So go gather all of Israel to meet me on Mount Carmel. Bring along 450 prophets of Baal and 400 prophets of the Asherah who are funded at Jezebel’s expense.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab sent for the Israelis and brought the prophets together at Mount Carmel,
speaker: Narrator

text:
where Elijah approached all the people and asked them, “How long will you keep hesitating between both sides? If the Lord is God, go after him. If Baal, go after him.”
But the people didn’t say a word.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elijah told the people, “I’m the only one left over as a prophet of the Lord, am I? But Baal’s prophets number 450 men?
speaker: Narrator

text: So let them provide two oxen. They can choose one ox for themselves. Cut it up, lay it on top of some wood, but don’t set fire to it. I will prepare the other ox and lay it on top of some wood, and I won’t set fire to it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you can call on the name of your god, and I’ll call on the name of the Lord. Let the God who answers by fire be our God!”
“That’s a good idea!” all the people shouted.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elijah told the prophets of Baal, “Choose an ox for yourselves and you prepare it first, since there are so many of you. Call on the name of your god, but don’t set fire to the offering.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they took the ox that was given to them, prepared it, and called on the name of Baal from early morning until noon. “Baal! Answer us!” they cried. But there was no response. Nobody answered. So they kept on dancing around the altar that they had made.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Starting about noon, Elijah began to tease them:
“Shout louder!
“He’s a god, so maybe he’s busy.
“Maybe he’s relieving himself.
“Maybe he’s busy someplace.
“Maybe he’s taking a nap and somebody needs to wake him up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the prophets of Baal cried even louder and slashed themselves with swords and lances until their blood gushed out all over them, as was their custom.
speaker: Narrator

text: They kept on raving right through midday and until it was time to offer the evening sacrifice, but there was still no response. Nobody answered, and nobody paid attention.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eventually, Elijah told everybody, “Come here!” So everybody approached him, and he repaired the Lord’s altar that had been torn down.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah took twelve stones, one for each of the tribes of Jacob’s descendants, to whom the message from the Lord had come that “Israel is to be your name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elijah used the stones to build an altar to the name of the Lord. But then he dug a trench around the altar large enough to hold two measures of seed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he laid the wood in order, cut the bull into pieces, and laid them on top of the wood.
“Fill four pitchers with water,” he ordered. “Then pour them out on the burnt offering and the wood.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do it a second time,” he ordered. So they did it a second time.
“Do it a third time,” he said. So they did it a third time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The water ran down around the altar and completely filled the trench.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the time for the evening offering arrived, Elijah the prophet approached and said, “Lord God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, let it be known today that you are God in Israel and that I, your servant, have done all of this in obedience to your word.
speaker: Narrator

text: Answer me, Lord! Answer me so that this people may know that you, Lord, are God, and that you are turning back their hearts again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Right then the Lord’s fire fell and consumed the burnt offering, the wood, the stones, the dust, and even the water that was in the trench!
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the people saw what had happened, they fell flat on their faces and cried out “The Lord is God! The Lord is God!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Elijah said, “Arrest the prophets of Baal. Don’t let even one of them get away.” So the people seized them, and Elijah brought them down to the Wadi Kishon and executed them there.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, Elijah told Ahab, “Get up and have something to eat and drink, because there’s the sound of a coming rainstorm.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab got up to get something to eat and drink while Elijah went back up to the top of Mount Carmel, where he bowed low to the ground and placed his face between his knees.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he told his young servant, “Go and look toward the sea.”
So he went and looked out to sea. “Nothing there,” he said.
But Elijah told him to go back seven times.
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the seventh look, he said, “Look! There’s a cloud, a small one, about the size of a man’s hand. It’s coming up out of the sea!”
“Get up and find Ahab!” Elijah said. “Tell him, ‘Mount your chariot and ride down the mountain so the storm doesn’t stop you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: A little while later, the sky turned black with storm clouds and winds, and there was a heavy shower. So Ahab rode off to Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Ahab had left, the hand of the Lord came upon Elijah, and he tucked his mantle into his belt and outran Ahab in a race to the city gate of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab complained to Jezebel about everything that Elijah had done, especially the part about him killing all the prophets of Baal with a sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jezebel sent a messenger to tell Elijah, “May the gods do the same to me and even more if tomorrow about this time I haven’t made you like one of those prophets you had killed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah was terrified, so he got up and ran for his life to Beer-sheba, which is part of Judah, and left his servant there
speaker: Narrator

text: and ran for a day’s journey deep into the wilderness. He found a juniper tree, sat down under it, and prayed that he could die. He asked God, “Enough! Lord! Take my life, because I’m not better than my ancestors!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he lay down and went to sleep under the juniper tree. All of a sudden, there was an angel, who kept grabbing him and telling him, “Get up! Eat!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he looked around, and there near his head was a muffin sitting on top of some heated stones, along with a jar of water. Elijah ate and drank and then lay down again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, the angel of the Lord came a second time, grabbed him, and said “Get up! Eat! The journey ahead is too difficult for you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elijah got up, ate and drank, and survived on that one meal for 40 days and nights as he set out on his journey to Horeb, God’s mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah arrived at a cave and stayed there. All of a sudden this message came from the Lord: “What are you doing here, Elijah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ve been very zealous for the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies,” he replied. “The Israelis have abandoned your covenant, demolished your altars, executed your prophets with swords, and I—that’s right, just me!—am the only one left. Now they’re seeking my life, to get rid of me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go out,” he responded, “and stand on the mountain in the presence of the Lord.” And there was the Lord, passing by! A tremendous, mighty windstorm was tearing at the mountains and breaking the rocks in pieces in the presence of the Lord, but the Lord was not in the windstorm. After the wind there came an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake.
speaker: Narrator

text: After the earthquake there came fire, but the Lord was not in the fire. And after the fire, there was the sound of a gentle whisper.
speaker: Narrator

text: As soon as Elijah heard it, he covered his face in his mantle, went outside, and stood at the entrance to the cave. And there a voice spoke to him and said, “What are you doing here, Elijah?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’ve been very zealous for the Lord God of the Heavenly Armies,” he replied. “The Israelis have abandoned your covenant, demolished your altars, executed your prophets with swords, and I—that’s right, just me!—am the only one left. Now they’re seeking my life, to get rid of me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord replied to him, “Go! Return to Damascus, and when you get there, anoint Hazael as king over Aram,
speaker: Narrator

text: anoint Nimshi’s son Jehu as king over Israel, and anoint Shaphat’s son Elisha from Abel-meholah as a prophet to replace you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whoever escapes from Hazael’s sword Jehu will execute, and whoever escapes from Jehu’s sword Elisha will put to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, I’ve reserved 7,000 in Israel who have neither bowed their knees to Baal nor kissed him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Elijah left there and located Shaphat’s son Elisha, who was plowing, along with a total of twelve pairs of oxen. (He was plowing with the twelfth pair.) As Elijah passed by, he tossed his cloak at Elisha.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He abandoned the oxen, ran off to follow Elijah, and asked him, “Please, let me kiss my mother and father good-bye, and then I’ll come after you.”
“Go back again,” Elijah replied. “What have I done to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Elisha turned back, took the pair of oxen, sacrificed them, boiled their flesh using the farm implements for fuel, and gave the food to the people with him. Then he got up, followed Elijah, and became his servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: A little while later, King Ben-hadad of Aram mustered an army of cavalry and chariots in a military confederacy with 32 kings, invaded Samaria, and set up siege encampments there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he sent envoys to visit King Ahab of Israel and told him, “This is what Ben-hadad says:
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Your silver and gold belong to me. So do the most beautiful of your wives and children.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Whatever you want, your majesty,” the king of Israel answered. “I belong to you, as does everything I own.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After delivering Ahab’s answer, the envoys returned with this message: “This is what Ben-hadad says: ‘I’ve sent my envoys to you to tell you that your silver, gold, wives, and children are to be given to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: About this time tomorrow, I’ll send my servants to you, and they’ll search through your palace and your servants’ houses. Whatever is important to you will be seized and taken away.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel called together all of the elders of the land and told them, “Please note that this man is here looking for trouble. He sent a message to me, demanding my wives, my children, and my silver and gold, and I haven’t refused him.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Don’t listen to him,” all the elders and the people replied. “And don’t agree to his terms.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he told Ben-hadad’s envoys, “Tell his majesty the king, ‘Everything that you asked for the first time I will do, but this thing I cannot do.’” So the envoys left to deliver Ahab’s response. They returned a little while later.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beh-hadad sent this message back: “May the gods do so to me, and more than that also, if the dust that remains of Samaria is enough to fill up a few handfuls for all of the armies at my disposal.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king of Israel replied, “Tell him, ‘The one who is starting to strap on his battle armor should never brag like the one who is taking it off.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ben-hadad received Ahab’s response while he was celebrating with his kings in the battle pavilions. “Sound ‘Battle Stations!’” he ordered, and the army began to prepare their attack.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, a prophet approached King Ahab of Israel and told him, “This is what the Lord says: ‘You see all of this great big army, do you? Well now, I’m going to deliver them all right into your hand, and you will learn that I am the Lord!’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“By whom?” Ahab asked.
“This is what the Lord says,” the prophet replied. “‘By the young men who serve as officials within the provinces.’”
“Who is to begin the battle?” Ahab asked.
“You,” the prophet answered.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ahab gathered together 232 young men who served as officials within the provinces and then mustered 7,000 soldiers from among the Israelis.
speaker: Narrator

text: They attacked at noon, just as Ben-hadad was drinking himself drunk in the battle pavilions, along with the 32 kings who had joined him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The young men who served as officials within the provinces led the charge, and somebody informed Ben-hadad, “Some men have come out from Samaria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take them alive, whether they’ve come in peace or not,” he ordered.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, as the young men who served as officials within the provinces left the city, their army followed after them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each man struck down his opponent, and the Arameans ran away with Israel in pursuit. King Ben-hadad of Aram escaped on horseback with the help of his cavalry.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel went out and attacked the cavalry and chariots and killed the Arameans in a massive victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: The prophet approached the king of Israel and told him, “Go replenish your forces and prepare for the future, because early this next year the king of Aram will attack you again.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Sure enough, the advisors to the king of Aram told him, “Their gods are mountain gods. That’s why they were stronger than we were. But when we fight them on the plains, we’re certain to be the stronger army!
speaker: Narrator

text: So do this: remove the kings from command and replace them with captains.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then replace the army that you lost, horse-for-horse and chariot-for-chariot. We’ll fight them on the plains, and we’re certain to be the stronger army.” Ben-hadad listened to what they had to say and carried out their advice.
speaker: Narrator

text: Early the next year, Ben-hadad mustered the Arameans and invaded Aphek in a battle against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelis were mustered, equipped with provisions, and sent out to fight. The Israeli encampment looked like two little flocks of goats compared to how the Aramean encampments filled the countryside!
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, a man of God approached and told the king of Israel, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Because the Arameans keep saying “The Lord is a mountain god, but isn’t a valley god,” I’m going to deliver this entire vast army right into your control, so you’ll learn that I really am the Lord.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they remained in opposing camps for seven days. Then on the seventh day the battle commenced, and the Israelis killed 100,000 Aramean infantry troops in a single day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The rest of the Aramean army retreated into Aphek, but the city wall collapsed on 27,000 soldiers who had taken shelter there. Ben-hadad himself ran away and hid inside a closet somewhere in the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Look, now,” his advisors suggested, “we’ve heard that the Israeli kings are merciful. So let’s clothe ourselves with sackcloth, tie our hair back with ropes, and go out to the king of Israel. Maybe he’ll spare your life.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So they put on some sackcloth, tied their hair back with ropes, and approached the king of Israel. “Your servant Ben-hadad says this,” they said. “Please let me live.”
“Is he still alive?” Ahab asked. “He’s my brother.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ben-hadad’s advisors, quickly analyzing the signs in what Ahab was saying, responded, “Yes, your brother Ben-hadad.”
“Go get him,” Ahab responded. So Ben-hadad came out to him, and Ahab took him up into his personal chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ben-hadad made this promise to Ahab: “I will restore the cities that my ancestors took from your ancestors. You’ll be able to build streets named after yourself in Damascus, as my father did in Samaria.”
“With this promise I will release you,” Ahab replied. So Ahab made a treaty with Ben-hadad and let him go.
speaker: Narrator

text: Right about then, one of the members of the guild of prophets told another through a message from the Lord: “Please strike me!” But the man refused to do so,
speaker: Narrator

text: so he told him, “Because you haven’t obeyed the Lord’s voice, as soon as you leave here, a lion will kill you.” As soon as the man left, a lion found him and killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, he found another man and told him, “Please strike me!” So the man struck him and wounded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet left and waited for the king to pass by, disguising himself with a bandage over his eyes.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the king was passing by, he cried out to the king and told him, “Your servant went out into the middle of the battle, and a soldier turned aside, brought a prisoner to me, and told me, ‘Guard this man. If he turns up missing for any reason at all, you’ll pay for it with your life or be fined one talent of silver.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
While your servant was busy here and there, the prisoner escaped.”
The king told him, “By your actions you’ve earned the proper judgment!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the prophet quickly tore off his bandage, and the king of Israel recognized him as being one of the prophets.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told the king, “This is what the Lord says: ‘Because you let the man whom I had dedicated to destruction go free, therefore your life is to be forfeited for his life, and your people for his people.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: After hearing this, the king of Israel rode back to his palace in Samaria, frustrated and in a foul mood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, there was a man named Naboth from Jezreel who owned a vineyard that was located contiguous to King Ahab’s palace in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab addressed Naboth and asked him, “I would like to plant a vegetable garden near my house. Please exchange your vineyard with a better one from me, or if you’d rather have cash, I’ll buy it for its full value.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Naboth replied to Ahab, “No way! The Lord prohibits the sale to you of the inheritance of my ancestors!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab went back to his palace, sullen and in a foul mood, because Naboth the Jezreelite had turned down Ahab’s offer by saying, “I will not transfer my ancestors’ inheritance to you!” He laid down on his bed, curled up with his face to the wall, and refused to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: But his wife Jezebel went to him and asked him, “How is it that you’re so sullen and refusing to eat?”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I asked Naboth the Jezreelite, ‘Sell me your vineyard for cash, or if you want, I’ll give you a better one in its place.’ But he refused. He told me, ‘I won’t give you my vineyard!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aren’t you the reigning king of Israel?” his wife Jezebel replied. “Get up, have a meal, and get ready to be happy. I’ll go get you the vineyard that Naboth the Jezreelite owns.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So she wrote some memos in Ahab’s name, set his personal seal to them, and sent them to the elders and nobles who lived with Naboth in his city.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the memos, she wrote the following directives: “Proclaim a public fast and seat Naboth in the front row.
speaker: Narrator

text: Seat two wicked men in front of him, and make them testify against him. Tell them to claim, ‘You cursed God and the king.’ Then take him out and stone him to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the leading men of the city, along with the elders and nobles who lived there, did precisely what Jezebel had directed them to do. They followed the instructions that she had set forth in the memos:
speaker: Narrator

text: They proclaimed a public fast and seated Naboth in the front row.
speaker: Narrator

text: Two wicked men came in, sat down in front of them, and testified against Naboth in public, “Naboth cursed God and the king!” So they took him outside the city and stoned him to death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterwards, they sent a message to Jezebel that said, “Naboth has been stoned. He’s dead.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned to death, she told Ahab, “Get up and confiscate Naboth’s vineyard that he refused to sell you for cash. Naboth the Jezreelite isn’t alive anymore. He’s dead!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So once he heard that Naboth was dead, Ahab got up, went down to the vineyard of Naboth the Jezreelite, and confiscated it.
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s when this message from the Lord came to Elijah the foreigner:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get up and go down to meet King Ahab of Israel. He’s in Samaria. Look! He’s in Naboth’s vineyard, where he’s gone to confiscate it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ask the king, ‘Did you commit murder? And now you’re going to steal as well?’ Also tell him, ‘This is what the Lord says: “Where the dogs were licking up Naboth’s blood, dogs will also lick up your blood—that’s right—yours!”’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Later on, Ahab asked Elijah, “Have you found me, my enemy?”
But Elijah answered, “I’ve found you because you sold yourself to do what the Lord considers to be evil!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now pay attention! I’m going to send evil in your direction! I will completely sweep you away and eliminate from Ahab every male, whether indentured servant or free, throughout Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make your household resemble that of Nebat’s son Jeroboam, or like the household of Ahijah’s son Baasha, because of how you’ve provoked me to anger and made Israel to sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord also has this to say about Jezebel: ‘Dogs will eat Jezebel within the outer ramparts of Jezreel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dogs will eat whoever belongs to Ahab and who dies in the city. The birds of the sky will eat whoever dies in the fields.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: It can be truly said that no one else sold himself to practice what the Lord considered to be evil quite like the way Ahab did, because his wife Jezebel incited him.
speaker: Narrator

text: His behavior in pursuing idolatry was detestable, just like the Amorites had done whom the Lord had expelled in front of the army of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, as soon as Ahab heard this message, he tore his clothes, put on sackcloth, and fasted. He even slept in sackcloth and wandered around meekly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, this message from the Lord came to Elijah the foreigner:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Have you noticed that Ahab has humbled himself in my presence? Because he has humbled himself in my presence, I will not bring his evil to harvest during his lifetime, but I will bring evil to his household during his son’s lifetime.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Three years passed without war between Aram and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: During that third year, King Jehoshaphat of Judah went to visit the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel asked his servants, “Were you aware that Ramoth-gilead belongs to us, but we aren’t doing anything to remove it from the control of the king of Aram?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he asked Jehoshaphat, “Will you join me in battle against Ramoth-gilead?”
“I’m with you,” Jehoshaphat answered the king of Israel. “My army will join yours, and my cavalry will be your cavalry.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoshaphat also asked the king of Israel, “Please ask for a message from the Lord, first.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So the king of Israel called in about 400 prophets and asked them, “Should we go attack Ramoth-gilead, or should I call off the attack?”
“Go attack them,” they all said, “because the Lord will drop them right into the king’s hand!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Isn’t there a prophet of the Lord left here that we could talk to?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“There is still one man left by whom we could ask the Lord what to do,” the king of Israel replied to Jehoshaphat, “but I hate him because he never prophesies anything good about me. Instead, he prophesies evil. He is Imla’s son Micaiah.”
But Jehoshaphat rebuked Ahab, “Kings should never talk like that.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless, the king of Israel called one of his officers and ordered him, “Bring me Imla’s son Micaiah quickly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah were each sitting on their respective thrones, arrayed in their robes, on the threshing floor at the entrance to the city gate of Samaria, and all of the prophets were prophesying in front of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Chenaanah’s son Zedekiah made iron horns for himself and told them, “This is what the Lord says, ‘With these horns you are to gore the Arameans until they are eliminated!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: All the other prophets were saying similar things, like “Go up to Ramoth-gilead and you will be successful, because the Lord will hand it over to the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the messenger who had gone off to summon Micaiah advised him, “Look, everything that the other prophets were saying was unanimously favorable to the king. So please, cooperate with them and speak favorably.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “As the Lord lives,” Micaiah replied, “I’ll say what my God tells me to say.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
When Micaiah approached the king, the king asked him, “Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramoth-gilead, or should I not?”
“Go to war,” Micaiah replied, “and you will be successful, because the Lord will hand it over to the king!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he heard this, the king asked him, “How many times do I have to make you swear to tell me nothing but the truth? Now do it in the name of the Lord!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
So Micaiah replied:
“I saw all of Israel
    scattered on the mountains
        like sheep without a shepherd.
And the Lord told me,
    ‘These have no master,
        so let them each return to his own home in peace.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, “Didn’t I tell you that he wouldn’t prophesy anything good about me, but only evil?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Micaiah responded, “Therefore, listen to what the Lord has to say. I saw the Lord, sitting on his throne, and the entire Heavenly Army was standing around him on his right hand and on his left hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord asked, ‘Who will tempt King Ahab of Israel to attack Ramoth-gilead, so that he will die there?’ And one was saying one thing and one was saying another.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But then a spirit approached, stood in front of the Lord, and said, ‘I will entice him.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“And the Lord asked him, ‘How?’
“‘I will go,’ he announced, ‘and I will be a deceiving spirit in the mouth of all of his prophets!’
“So the Lord said, ‘You’re just the one to deceive him. You will be successful. Go and do it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now therefore, listen! The Lord has placed a lying spirit in the mouth of all of these prophets of yours, because the Lord has determined to bring disaster upon you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Right then, Chenaanah’s son Zedekiah approached Micaiah and struck him on the cheek. Then he asked him, “How did the Spirit of the Lord move from me to speak to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Micaiah replied, “You’ll see how when the day comes that you run away to hide yourself in a closet!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king of Israel ordered, “Take Micaiah and place him in the custody of Amon, the city governor. Hand him over to Joash, the king’s son.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give him this order: ‘Place him in prison on survival rations of bread and water only until I come back safely.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: “If you return alive,” Micaiah responded, “then the Lord has not spoken by me.” Then he added, “Listen, all you people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah both attacked Ramoth-gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king of Israel suggested to Jehoshaphat, “I’ll go into battle in disguise, but you keep your royal uniform on.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and they both went into the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, the king of Aram had issued these orders to 32 of his chariot commanders: “Don’t attack unimportant soldiers or ranking officers. Go after only the king of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So when the chariot commanders observed Jehoshaphat, they said by mistake, “It’s the king of Israel!” and they turned aside to attack him. But Jehoshaphat cried out.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the chariot commanders saw that their target was not the king of Israel, they stopped pursuing him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, somebody drew his bow aimlessly and struck the king of Israel between the scales where his armor breastplates joined, so he instructed his chariot driver, “Turn around and take me out of the battle, because I’ve been severely wounded.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The battle continued on for the rest of the day while the king of Israel was propped up in front of the Arameans until the sun set, at which time he died. The blood from Ahab’s wound ran down into the bottom of the chariot.
speaker: Narrator

text: As the day drew to a close, this order was circulated throughout the army telling the soldiers, “Everybody go back to his city and to his own land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king died and was brought back to Samaria, and they buried the king in Samaria.
speaker: Narrator

text: They washed the chariot by the reservoir of Samaria, and the dogs licked up his blood near where the prostitutes went to bathe, in keeping with the message that the Lord had spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now as to the rest of Ahab’s accomplishments, everything that he undertook, the ivory palace he built, and the cities that he built, they are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: That’s how Ahab died, just as his ancestors had, and his son Ahaziah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asa’s son Jehoshaphat became king over Judah during the fourth year of the reign of King Ahab of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat was 35 years old when he became king. He reigned 25 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Azubah. She was the daughter of Shilhi.
speaker: Narrator

text: He lived like his father Asa and never abandoned that life. He did what the Lord considered to be right. Nevertheless, the high places were not demolished, and the people continued to sacrifice and burn incense on the high places.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat also made a peace treaty with the king of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the rest of Jehoshaphat’s accomplishments, the power that he demonstrated, and how he waged war are written in the book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah, are they not?
speaker: Narrator

text: He also eliminated the male cult prostitutes who still remained from the time of his father Asa.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was no king reigning in Edom; there was only a stand-in king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoshaphat had ocean-going vessels from Tarshish sail to Ophir for gold, but they never made it because they were shipwrecked at Ezion-geber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab’s son Ahaziah had offered to go. “Let my servants go with your servants in the ships!” he said. But Jehoshaphat was not willing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later, Jehoshaphat died, as did his ancestors, and he was buried alongside his ancestors in the City of David. Jehoram his son became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahab’s son Ahaziah became king over Israel in Samaria in the seventeenth year of King Jehoshaphat of Judah. He reigned for two years over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He practiced what the Lord considered to be evil by living life like his father and mother did. He lived like Nebat’s son Jeroboam, who led Israel into sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: He served Baal, worshipped him, and provoked the Lord God of Israel to anger, in accordance with everything his father had done.
speaker: Narrator
